factoid: Natásha nodded to the dressmaker.
Natásha knew the dressmaker.
The dressmaker curtsied respectfully to Natásha.
Natásha seated herself in an armchair beside the looking glass.
Natásha draped the folds of her velvet dress picturesquely.
Natásha did not cease chattering good-naturedly and gaily.
Natásha continually praised her own beauty.
Natásha looked at her dresses and praised them.
Natásha praised a new dress of her own made of metallic gauze.
Natásha received the new dress from Paris.
Natásha advised her to have a dress like the metallic gauze one.
Natásha remarked, "But anything suits you, my charmer!"
A smile of pleasure never left Natásha’s face.
Natásha felt happy.
Natásha felt as if she were blossoming under the praise of Countess Bezúkhova.
Countess Bezúkhova had formerly seemed unapproachable and important to Natásha.
Countess Bezúkhova was now kind to Natásha.
Natásha brightened up.
Natásha felt almost in love with Countess Bezúkhova.
Countess Bezúkhova was beautiful.
Countess Bezúkhova was kind.
Hélène was sincerely delighted with Natásha.
Hélène wished to give Natásha a good time.
Anatole had asked Hélène to bring him and Natásha together.
Hélène was calling on the Rostóvs for that purpose.
Hélène found the idea of throwing her brother and Natásha together amusing.
Natásha did not think of the earlier annoyance in Petersburg now.
Natásha heartily wished Natásha well.
As Natásha was leaving the Rostóvs, she called her protégée aside.
Natásha’s brother dined with her yesterday.
Natásha’s brother nearly died of laughter.
Natásha’s brother ate nothing and kept sighing for Natásha.
Natásha’s brother is madly in love with Natásha.
Natásha blushed scarlet when she heard this.
Hélène said, "How she blushes, how she blushes, my pretty!"
Hélène said, "You must certainly come."
Hélène said, "If you love somebody, my charmer, that is not a reason to shut yourself up."
Hélène said, "Even if you are engaged, I am sure your fiancé would wish you to go into society rather than be bored to death."
Natásha said, "So she knows I am engaged, and she and her husband Pierre have talked and laughed about this."
Natásha said, "So it’s all right."
Under Hélène’s influence, what had seemed terrible now seemed simple and natural.
Natásha thought, "And she is such a grande dame, so kind, and evidently likes me so much. And why not enjoy myself?"
Natásha gazed at Hélène with wide-open, wondering eyes.
Márya Dmítrievna came back to dinner taciturn and serious.
Márya Dmítrievna had evidently suffered a defeat at the old prince’s.
Márya Dmítrievna was still too agitated by the encounter to be able to talk of the affair calmly.
In answer to the count’s inquiries, Márya replied that things were all right.
Márya said she would tell about it the next day.
Márya heard of Countess Bezúkhova’s visit and the invitation for that evening.
Márya remarked, "I don’t care to have anything to do with Bezúkhova and don’t advise you to; however, if you’ve promised—go. It will divert your thoughts."
Count Rostóv took the girls to Countess Bezúkhova’s.
There were many people there, but nearly all strangers to Natásha.
Count Rostóv was displeased to see that the company consisted almost entirely of men and women known for the freedom of their conduct.
Mademoiselle George was standing in a corner of the drawing room surrounded by young men.
Several Frenchmen were present, among them Métivier who from the time Hélène reached Moscow had been an intimate in her house.
The count decided not to sit down to cards or let his girls out of his sight and to get away as soon as Mademoiselle George’s performance was over.
Anatole was at the door, evidently on the lookout for the Rostóvs.
After greeting the count, Anatole went up to Natásha and followed her.
When Natásha saw Anatole, she was seized by the same feeling she had at the opera—gratified vanity at his admiration of her and fear at the absence of a moral barrier between them.
Hélène welcomed Natásha delightedly and was loud in admiration of her beauty and her dress.
Soon after their arrival, Mademoiselle George went out of the room to change her costume.
In the drawing room people began arranging the chairs and taking their seats.
Anatole moved a chair for Natásha and was about to sit down beside her, but the count, who never lost sight of her, took the seat himself.
Anatole sat down behind Natásha.
